2001 College Championship quarterfinal game 4.
From the campus at UCLA.

double_jeopardy_round: LOSING YOUR HEAD IN THE MOVIES

(1, 1).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew reports from the San Diego Zoo.)  All apes, including the siamang, are, unfortunately, now on this list

(2, 1).clue: Introduced in 1886, a classic 6-prong setting for engagement rings is named for this Manhattan jewelry store

(3, 1).clue: Dude!  There are 30-footers breakin' at Waimea Bay on the North Shore in this state

(4, 1).clue: Guy Ritchie directed the controversial video for her "What It Feels Like For A Girl"

(5, 1).clue: In the '60s Katharine Graham took over as publisher of this newspaper & hired Ben Bradlee as managing editor

(1, 2).clue: Hermit crabs have 2 pairs of antennae & 4 pairs of these

(2, 2).clue: It's said that pins weren't worn on kilts until this 19th c. queen offered one to a Highland soldier on a windy day

(3, 2).clue: Bummer!  In 2001 a pro event on the southern tip of East Java in this country was scrubbed due to civil unrest

(4, 2).clue: Destiny's Child sings in a lagoon in this jungle-set video

(5, 2).clue: In 2001 McCall's magazine was relaunched with this TV talk show host at the helm & renamed for her

(6, 2).clue: Bogus or fake, like some money

(1, 3).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew reports from SeaWorld.)  The otter is the most aquatically adapted of this animal family

(2, 3).clue: Most folks think of this January birthstone as reddish, but lovely orange ones are found in Namibia & Nigeria

(3, 3).clue: It's surfin' among the future sushi where you hit the waves at Chiba's Torami Beach in this country

(4, 3).clue: This actor dances his way through the Fatboy Slim video "Weapon Of Choice"

(5, 3).clue: This alternative music magazine founded by Bob Guccione Jr. celebrated its 15th anniversary in 2000

(1, 4).clue: Strains of the Norway species of this animal are the ones used in labs

(2, 4).clue: Often green or white, nephrite is a type of this gemstone closely associated with Asia

(3, 4).clue: Whoa!  I took a donut (wiped out) at Burleigh during the Billabong Pro on this country's Gold Coast

(4, 4).clue: Lingerie-clad Christina Aguilera, Mya, Lil' Kim & Pink all appear in this video

(5, 4).clue: Roger Ebert writes movie reviews for this Midwestern paper

(6, 4).clue: A valuable family possession handed down from one generation to the next

(1, 5).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports from the San Diego Zoo.)  Unlike humans, sheep don't have these front cutting teeth on their upper jaw, but they do have eight on their lower jaw

(2, 5).clue: "Jurassic Park" made this fossilized resin really popular; maybe you'll find some dinosaur DNA in yours

(3, 5).clue: Head to Jeffreys Bay & pull off a sick floater in this country, whose administrative capital is Pretoria

(4, 5).clue: 5 of this woman's 6 MTV Video Music Award nominations were courtesy of her work with Eminem on "Stan"

(5, 5).clue: After the demise of Sassy, founding editor Ms. Pratt launched this magazine that bears her first name

(6, 5).clue: The only U.S. President whose last name fits the category

(1, 1).clue: Completes the title of Edward Gibbon's masterpiece "The History of the Decline and Fall of..."

(2, 1).clue: This Cherokee Indian gave his name to both a giant tree & the California nat'l park where you'll find it

(3, 1).clue: You don't need any super powers to know that Kr is the chemical symbol for this noble gas

(4, 1).clue: In this film Christina Ricci loses her head over Johnny Depp who's chasing a headless murderer

(6, 1).clue: Hannibal Lecter could tell you it's an equal exchange; its Latin meaning is "something for something"

(1, 2).clue: The heroine of his novel "Roxana" leads almost as saucy a life as his more famous Moll Flanders

(2, 2).clue: She once whisked Eleanor Roosevelt away for an airplane ride over Washington, both still in evening gowns

(3, 2).clue: The temperature of this smokeless laboratory heating device is controlled by the amount of air in the tube

(4, 2).clue: Film in which Jennings loses his head over a little boy named Damien with a devil-may-care attitude

(6, 2).clue: From the Old French for "man", it's a special honor expressed publicly for a person

(1, 3).clue: E.M. Forster & Virginia Woolf were part of a floral-sounding literary "Group" named for this London district

(2, 3).clue: It's the last name of famed anthropologists Louis, Mary, Richard & Meave

(3, 3).clue: It's a substance that reacts with an acid to decrease or neutralize its acidic properties; lye, for example

(4, 3).clue: In this 1998 film Michael Myers loses his head over Jamie Lee Curtis 20 years after their first date

(6, 3).clue: The name of this sea may come from the Lithuanian word for "white"

(1, 4).clue: One of his most famous works, "A child's Christmas in Wales", wasn't published until 2 years after his death

(2, 4).clue: "Father of the Supercomputer" who once said, "I was one of those nerds before the name was popular"

(3, 4).clue: (Hi, I'm Doctor Alan Heger, Nobel Prize-winner in Chemistry.)  These large molecules are formed by the chemical linking of smaller molecules; nylon is a synthetic one

(4, 4).clue: Brad Pitt uncovers the deadly sin, as wife Gwyneth Paltrow loses her head over Kevin Spacey in this movie

(6, 4).clue: Representative of the world in miniature, it's from the Greek for "small world"

(1, 5).clue: An African safari is the setting for his famous story "The Short Happy Life of Francis Macomber"

(2, 5).clue: In 1850 this "colorful" Scotsman founded one of the first detective agencies in the U.S.

(3, 5).clue: In this type of bond, 2 bonded atoms each contribute 1 electron to a pair, which the atoms then share

(4, 5).clue: In this film David Gale loses his head over Jeffrey Combs; in the sequel grafted bat wings give him new life

(6, 5).clue: Meaning empty boasting, it comes from the name of a loud-mouthed braggart in Spenser's "The Faerie Queene"

(0, 0).clue: A 1904 issue of Popular Science Monthly reported their success in North Carolina the previous year
